LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
   
Borrower  India 
 
Classification  Poverty: Poverty Intervention 
  Thematic: Good Governance and Economic Growth 
 
The Proposal  Two  loans  to  India  for  the  Madhya  Pradesh  State  Roads 
Sector  Development  Program  (SDP)  to  support  Madhya 
Pradesh’s state road sector reform and rehabilitate the fast 
deteriorating state road network, comprising (i) a program 
loan and a project loan, and (ii) proposed administration of 
technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening and 
Capacity Building for Madhya Pradesh State Road Sector. 
   
Rationale  Due to inadequate institutional and technical capability of the 
current public works department system in Madhya Pradesh, 
the Public Works Department of the Government of Madhya 
Pradesh (PWDGoMP) can fulfill very limited responsibilities to 
manage  the  state  road  sector.  This  has  resulted  in  rapid 
deterioration  of  the  state  road  network,  quickly  increased 
road transport capacity bottlenecks, unreliable road transport 
services for the state economy and the poor, who comprise 
38%  of  the  total  population  in  Madhya  Pradesh.  This,  in 
combination with inefficient use of scarce financial resources 
for  road  maintenance,  has  become  one  of  the  major 
constraints to the state’s social and economic development.  
   
  To  rectify  the  situation  and  enable  the  Madhya  Pradesh 
Government (MPG) to manage the state road network more 
effectively and efficiently, and ensure reliable road transport 
services  to  support  the  state’s  economic  and  social 
development, institutional reform has become crucial.  
   
  The reform is expected to help establish a transparent and 
conducive environment for private sector participation that will 
improve  the  effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  road  sector 
management, and foster competition. This will in turn ensure 
better infrastructure facilities and decrease recurrent costs for 
road maintenance over the medium- and long-terms to allow 
higher capital and expenditure for priority social sectors and 
poverty reduction. Furthermore, the investment component 
will  generate  employment  opportunities  and  benefit  other 
sectors, thereby contributing to poverty reduction.  
   
  Madhya Pradesh is a focal state for ADB’s lending activities.  
Thus,  two  loans  were  approved,  one  for  public  sector 
resource management and the other for power sector reform. 
The SDP will be ADB’s first loan to the state road sector.

ii 
ADB  has,  together  with  the  Government  of  India  (the 
Government), developed a holistic approach to guide ADB’s 
interventions in the state road sector. 
   
  The medium- to long-term objectives of ADB’s operations are 
to (i) improve governance and accountability of the sector 
management  by  reengineering  the  current  Public  Works 
Department  structure  and  building  capacity,  (ii)  initiate  an 
enabling environment for better private sector participation in 
development of the sector, and (iii) establish a more effective 
asset management mechanism and sustainable funding of 
road  maintenance.  The  SDP  focuses  on  the  institutional 
reengineering  of  PWDGoMP  and  capacity  building  for  a 
reliable institutional framework for more effective and efficient 
state road sector management. 
 
The Program Loan   
   
Objectives  The  main  objective  of  the  Program  is  to  enable  MPG  to 
establish  a  more  effective  and  efficient  state  road  sector 
management  system  and  ensure  reliable  road  transport 
services to support Madhya Pradesh economic and social 
development, and thus reduce poverty. 
   
Components and Outputs  The objectives of the Program are  to be achieved through (i) 
instituting measures for good governance in administration 
and management of the sector, (ii) improving capability and 
building capacity for effective road asset management, (iii) 
building capacity to improve institutional effectiveness and 
efficiency, and (iv) initiating steps to identify pilot cases for 
outsourcing and better private sector participation.  
   
  The  implementation  of  the  Program  requires  MPG  to 
undertake a number of policy actions, including (i) setting up 
a state highway zone (SHZ) within PWDGoMP as an interim 
measure with necessary staffing and institutional authority to 
integrate key responsibilities and functions to manage state 
roads, implement the SDP, and prepare for transforming the 
SHZ into the SHA; (ii) transforming  the SHZ into the SHA as 
a self-contained and fully functional agency to take over state 
road management; (iii) staffing the SHA, at headquarters and 
regional levels, with the right skills  to make it a lean and 
efficient  organization  responsible  for  road  sector  policy, 
resource  management,  development  planning  and  asset 
management;  (iv)  implementing  modern  planning  and 
decision-making tools and preparing 5 year and annual road 
sector  development  and  maintenance  plans  based  on 
economic  and  other  clearly-defined  sector  performance 
criteria; (v) improving internal business processes to enhance 
operational  and  financial  efficiency,  management

iii 
accountability,  transparency,  and  service  quality;  (vi) 
implementing a staff rationalization program as approved by 
MPG through implementing a labor rationalization program  
following the Government’s –Voluntary Retirement Scheme 
for  government  employees  and  statutory  reduction  of 
nonpermanent employees following the Industrial Dispute Act 
1947 to free  more funds for road maintenance works; (vii) 
securing adequate budget allocation to ensure sustainable 
funding of road maintenance in the near term until further 
economic  development  and  traffic  growth  support 
establishment  of  a  road  maintenance  fund;  and  (viii) 
introducing effective vehicle overloading controls to preserve 
roads and road safety programs to reduce road deaths and 
injuries. 
   
Financing  Plan  A loan of $30 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources 
  will be provided under ADB’s London Interbank Offered Rate- 
  based (LIBOR-based) lending facility. The loan will have a 
  term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years, an 
  interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-
  based lending facility and other terms and conditions set forth 
  in the draft Loan Agreements. 
   
  The  Program  will  be  implemented  over  30  months.  The 
program loan of $30 million will be released in two tranches. 
The first tranche of $12 million is anticipated to be released in 
December  2002.  The  second  tranche  of  $18  million  is 
expected to be released by June 2005. 
   
Executing Agency  The  Executing  Agency  for  the  program  loan  is  the 
Department  of  Finance  of  the  Government  of  Madhya 
Pradesh (FDGoMP). 
   
  The proceeds of the program loan will finance the foreign 
exchange costs (excluding local taxes and duties) of eligible 
items  produced  in  and  procured  from  ADB’s  member 
countries, other than items specified in the negative list in the 
program loan agreement, and imports to be financed by other 
bilateral and multilateral sources. 
   
  Counterpart funds generated by the program loan proceeds 
will be transferred by the Government of India to MPG and be 
used by MPG under arrangements satisfactory to ADB, to 
support the reform and meet the adjustment costs associated 
with the Program as agreed upon by the Borrower, including 
implementation  of  labor  rationalization,    road  safety,    and  
overloading control programs. 
   
The Project Loan   
   
Objectives  The project will rehabilitate the dramatically deteriorated and

iv 
damaged  state  road  corridors  to  provide  reliable  road 
transport  services  and  support  social  and  economic 
development programs, and thus reduce poverty. 
 
   
Components and Outputs  The Project is designed to rehabilitate about 1,750 kilometers 
of state roads identified from important state road corridors, 
including (i) state roads linking with the north-south national 
highway  corridor,  important  industrial  centers,  and  major 
district  roads;  (ii)  state  roads  with  relatively  high  traffic 
volumes  providing  transport  services  for  the  predominant 
agricultural production; (iii) rural connectivity roads to benefit 
the rural poor with better access to the mainstream economy 
and  business  opportunities;  (iv)  equipment  necessary  for 
PWDGoMP  to  ensure  quality  control,  improve  operational 
efficiency, and provide emergency relief; and (v) consulting

Procurement and Consulting  ADB has approved advance procurement for phase I civil 
Services  works  (about  350  km  of  state  highways)  and  consulting 
services for construction supervision. All procurement to be

v 
financed  under  the  project  loan  will  be  carried  out  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement. 
Consulting services to be financed under the project loan will 
be  recruited  using  quality  and  cost-based  selection    in

Benefits and Beneficiaries  The  social  and  poverty  assessments  show  that  the  main 
beneficiaries of the SDP are people living in the predominant 
agricultural,  rural,  and  economically  backward  areas.  The 
SDP is expected to benefit 10 million people in a 30 km zone 
of influence around the state roads to be improved. Of these, 
an estimated 5 million poor people will be direct beneficiaries, 
or about 50% of the total direct beneficiaries. 
   
  The main quantifiable benefits of the Project are (i) savings in 
vehicle operating costs, which will be passed on to the rural 
poor through service providers; and (ii) savings in travel time.  
Nonquantifiable  benefits  will  be  realized  through  improved 
access  to  markets  and  social  services  for  agricultural 
population and rural poor, which reflects higher profit for poor 
farmers, and lower cost and more timely access to schools, 
medical clinics, and employment centers. 
   
  The Project will help reduce poverty by lowering transport 
costs for the poor farmers and lower cost and more timely 
access to schools, medical clinics, and employment centers.  
The lower transport costs will also increase mobility among 
the poor, especially poor women going to social centers, and 
allow them to become more politically active, thus increasing 
their empowerment.  
   
  The reform is expected to involve reduction of approximately 
7,800 permanent and 8,000 nonpermanent employees. To 
ensure compliance with ADB’s social protection framework, 
MPG has adopted a social safety net program to provide job 
counseling, information services, and training. 
   
Environmental Assessment  The Project is classified as environment category B. 
and Social Measures  An initial environmental examination (IEE) was undertaken 
  and the summary IEE is a supplementary appendix. Social 
impacts of the SDP will be mitigated through implementation 
of  a  social  safety  net  program  under  the  Program.  The 
Project will have minimal social impacts on the project area, 
which can be mitigated.  
   
Technical Assistance  TA for Institutional Strengthening and Capacity Building for 
Madhya Pradesh State Road Sector has been designed to 
assist MPG to implement the institutional reform. Specifically,

vi 
the TA will (i) help MPG build institutional capacity to support 
recovery  and  development  of  the  state  road  network;  (ii) 
strengthen  PWDGoMP’s  capabilities  in  transport  planning, 
project  financing  and  investment  management,  and 
environmental  management  by  introducing  internationally 
recognized  principles;  (iii)  provide  training  programs  to 
disseminate  findings  and  recommendations  on  the  reform 
and improvement of the state road sector management; and 
(iv) assist PWDGoMP to implement the labor rationalization  
and  social safety net programs for the employees to be 
retrenched. The TA will be financed by the Government of the 
United Kingdom for $1.5 million and MPG for $0.4 million 
equivalent  in  kind  and  administered  by  ADB.  About  84 
person-months  of  international  and  domestic  consulting 
services will be required. 
   
Risks and Safeguards  Risks to the sector reform relate to MPG’s political will and 
implementation  abilities  in  making  policy  changes  and 
mitigating adverse impacts because it focuses on governance 
and staff rationalization. MPG has successfully implemented 
similar  reforms  in  the  power  sector  and  public  resource 
management with ADB assistance. MPG has developed the 
capacity  required  for  handling  labor  issues  through 
implementing a voluntary retirement scheme for public sector 
undertakings, although this is the first time that government 
employees will be involved in a labor rationalization program. 
Additionally, ADB will conduct frequent policy dialogue with 
MPG  and  strengthen  supervision  and  review  of  program 
implementation to ensure that the reform objectives are well 
understood, the long-term reform agenda is kept on track, 
and policy actions are taken as stated in the policy matrix. 
The  tranching  and  monitoring  of  compliance  with  tranche 
release  conditions  have  incorporated  time-bound  reform 
measures to ensure successful implementation of the reform. 
The  associated  TA  will  further  strengthen  PWDGoMP’s 
implementation capacity and help it implement the reform. 
   
  Risks for the Project are limited to ensuring quality control 
due to PWDGoMP’s limited capacity to carry out effective 
contract management and supervision of works. However, 
this  can  be  mitigated  by  hiring  consulting  services  for 
construction supervision and capacity building programs for 
PWDGoMP  on  contract  management  and  quality  control. 
Contracts have been divided into relatively large packages to 
attract international and large qualified domestic contractors 
to ensure good performance by contractors and high quality 
construction.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) two proposed 
loans to India for the Madhya Pradesh State Roads Sector Development Program (SDP) that 
comprises a Program Loan and a Project Loan; and (ii) proposed administration of technical 
assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening and Capacity Building for Madhya Pradesh State 
Road Sector. 
 
 
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
1.  Recent Macroeconomic Performance and Prospects 
2.  Madhya Pradesh was one of the poorest states in India. It was the largest state in land 
area and fourth in population until it was bifurcated into Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh on 1 
November  2000  in  accordance  with  the  Madhya  Pradesh  Reorganization  Act  2000.  The 
bifurcation made Madhya Pradesh lose its rich coal, iron ore, limestone, and forest resources, 
which were prime sources of industrial growth in Madhya Pradesh before the bifurcation. The 
state economy had shown robust growth averaging 4.4% since 1980, accelerating to 5% during 
1990–1996.  While  contribution  of  the  primary  sector  in  state  domestic  product  declined 
gradually from 43.4 % in 1993 to 39.6% in 1999, the contribution of services and industry rose 
consistently from 21.4% to 23% % during the same period.  
 
3.  After bifurcation, Madhya Pradesh retained about two thirds of its former land area and 
population, but has lost most of its natural resources to Chhattisgarh. Agriculture dominates the 
economy, with small manufacturing and service sectors. The economy has been performing 
poorly since 1996 with a weakening revenue base, as shown by the recent budget review under 
the Asian Development Bank(ADB)-financed Public Sector Resource Management Program1, 
and fiscal deficit increasing from 5.4% in 1999 to 8% in 2001.   
 
4.  Structural impediments have prevented the economy from reaching its potential given 
the  liberalized  policy  environment.  In  particular,  the  deteriorating  fiscal  health  of  the  state 
government has significantly undermined the economy’s long-term growth potential because of 
inadequate public investment. Industrial recession, acute power shortages and fast deterioration 
of  transport  infrastructure  facilities  led  to  a  sharp  decline  in  industrial  growth  in  Madhya 
Pradesh. The growth rate of the state’s real net domestic product of registered manufacturing 
declined from 7.1% in 1994 to 4.4% in 1996, and to 1.1% in 1997. Many industrial units were 
forced to shut down, leading to large-scale unemployment. Many designated economic growth 
centers  in  Madhya  Pradesh  failed  to  promote  industrialization  due  to  the  lack  of  basic 
infrastructure such as roads. A recent survey by the Public Works Department of the Goernment 
of Madhya Pradesh (PWDGoMP) has shown that Madhya Pradesh’s economy is severely 
constrained by poor road infrastructure. State roads are generally in very poor condition. The

2.  Transport Sector 
 
6.  Railways connecting north-south and east-west regions of India pass through Madhya 
Pradesh with a total length of about 5,900 km. However, due to Madhya Pradesh's vast area, 
the railway services cannot provide the desired connectivity to major economic zones and 
centers. The railway network traversing Madhya Pradesh serves the needs of cross-country 
traffic more than those of Madhya Pradesh. In total, 11 major districts in Madhya Pradesh  have 
little rail service. Civil aviation, port, and inland waterway have very limited role in the state’s 
overall economy and transport services.  As a result, roads are the predominant mode of 
transport services. 
 
7.  Madhya  Pradesh  has  202,240  kilometers  (km)  of  roads,  of  which  57,205  km  are 
surfaced. State has 7,923 km of state highways, 4,717 km of national highways, 30,070 km of 
district roads, and 159,530 of rural roads. Of the rural roads, 25,033 km are under PWDGoMP’s 
jurisdiction while the remaining 134,497 km are under the responsibility of Madhya Pradesh 
Rural Road Development Authority (MPRRDA) and local village authorities (panchayats). 
 
3.  Road Sector Institutions and Responsibilities 
 
8.  The  public  works  department  (PWD)  system  dates  back  to  the  mid-1850s,  and  is 
outmoded. Since then, the system has monopolized engineering, construction supervision, and 
maintenance services for all infrastructure facilities. Because of the monopoly, the system 
generates no incentive to adopt modern managerial mechanisms or to operate more efficiently. 
The  system  does  not  provide  local  consultants  and  contractors  with  a  transparent  and 
competitive environment or opportunities to develop their capacity and competitiveness. This, in 
combination with the outdated knowledge and skills and management system, has made the 
PWD system inefficient and ineffective. Its implementation capabilities are also very limited due 
to the slow turnover of staff and little opportunity for promotion and career development. 
 
9.  PWDGoMP oversees planning, design, construction, and maintenance of all state roads, 
major  bridges,  and  government  and  public  services  buildings.  Jointly  with  local  district 
governments, it is responsible for district roads, some village roads, small bridges, and other 
buildings. It is also responsible for maintenance of national highways under the delegated 
authority  and  responsibility  by  the  Ministry  of  Road  Transport  and  Highways  (MORTH). 
Responsibility  for  construction  and  maintenance  of  most  village  roads  rests  with  Madhya 
Pradesh’s rural engineering services and MPRRDA. PWDGoMP’s poor capability in effective 
planning and programming, low capacity for management and quality control for construction 
and  maintenance,  serious  shortage  of  financial  resources,  and  ineffective  management  of 
financial resources has resulted in substantive investment deficiencies in the state’s road sector, 
and gross lack of maintenance of the road network.

3 
10.  Licensing, registration, and regulation of motor vehicles, drivers, and passenger and 
freight transport is with the Madhya Pradesh Transport Department (MPTD). In 2001, over 2.9 
million motor vehicles were registered of which 74% were motorcycles, 5% were cars and jeeps, 
3% commercial trucks, 2% buses and minibuses, 2% two- and three-wheeler public transport 
vehicles, 9% tractors, and 5% others. The state-owned Madhya Pradesh State Road Transport 
Corporation (MPSRTC) operates only 3% of the state’s buses. Private sector operators provide 
most of the services for passenger and freight transport. MPTD is also responsible for  enforcing 
axle load regulations. It has a system of 39 weigh stations at entry points into the state, and 
mobile squads to carry out its responsibilities. Traffic police are responsible for enforcing traffic 
and road safety regulations. The traffic police are under the Police Department. 
 
4.  Sector Performance  
 
11.  PWDGoMP performs inadequately in its responsibility and accountability for managing 
state roads, mainly due to a lack of clear objectives, technical capability, and institutional 
capacity in sector policy formulation, investment planning and programming, project formulation, 
project execution, and management of road maintenance.  
 
12.  PWDGoMP has too many personnel2 who account for more than 67% of the nonplanned 
budget (for recurrent expenditures) or 29% of the total budget allocated to PWDGoMP for salary 
payment, thus reducing the available budget for materials and equipment essential for effective 
road  maintenance.  The  skills  mix  is  inadequate  for  contemporary  needs.  A  hiring  freeze 
intended  to  limit  numbers  has  meant  that  engineers  with  up-to-date  skills  have  not  been 
recruited. Training is only provided in administrative procedures, and professional staff have no 
means of upgrading their technical skills. Opportunities for promotion are limited. As a result, 
PWDGoMP cannot maintain standards. Professional staff are discouraged and accountability is 
not enforced.  The result is poor governance and poor sector management. 
 
13.  Management of state roads is linked to a very general development strategy and is not 
based  on  performance.  Procedural  delays  in  administrative  processes  have  resulted  in 
inefficient use of funds. Financial accounting and financial management systems are simple 
bookkeeping  system  performed  manually  and  recorded  in  a  loose  archive  system.  Road 
planning is inadequate and suffers from a lack of reliable data. There is no ongoing process for 
identifying  needs  and  planning  responses  based  on  a  development  strategy  and  applying 
economic criteria. Data required for strategic planning such as road and bridge inventories, 
condition, traffic, and accident locations are limited and not updated (the last official traffic 
update was in 1995). 
 
14.  In-house technical design capacity is limited and used only for minor works.  Road 
construction  methods  are  generally  outdated,  inefficient,  and  low  quality.  Construction 
supervision by staff is mainly process-oriented without effective mechanisms to control quality, 
progress,  and  costs.  Routine  maintenance  is  ineffective  because  there  is  insufficient 
nonplanedn budget for materials, plant, and equipment. Plant and equipment are obsolete.3 
Gang labor is unproductive. There is no system of maintenance planning and accountability for 
performance. Periodic maintenance is carried out mainly through contracting but supervision 
and quality control are inadequate.  A detailed analysis is provided in Appendix 1.

reliable statistics and performance measures of previous programs and activities. Particularly, it 
is difficult for PWDGoMP to extrapolate detailed information on budget use and personnel 
management to support its planning process and decisions on sector policies and reforms.  
 
16.  Overloading  of  vehicles  is  widespread,  magnifying  poor  road  conditions  created  by 
inadequate maintenance. MPTD data show that over 90% of the trucks passing through weigh 
stations are overloaded. This is also a national problem as most of the trucks are on interstate 
journeys. MPTD needs to strengthen enforcement of vehicle weight regulations.  Road safety is 
a serious problem, and death4 and injury rates are high in comparison to developed countries.  
The Police Department collects accident data and has a road safety education program but 
PWDGoMP does not appear to consider road safety as a part of its mandate. There is a need to 
establish a road safety program in PWDGoMP to eliminate road safety hazards.  
 
17.  Private sector operators provide most road transport services. Services are generally 
adequate but travel is arduous and time-consuming due to the poor road conditions. The private 
sector does not provide services to many outlying districts and services to these districts have to 
be provided by the state-owned MPRTC. The maximum fare that can be charged are regulated 
by MPTD and is presently set at Rs0.40 /km, which is one of the highest rates in India. Better 
roads will reduce vehicle-operating costs and lead to lower fares.

C.  The Rationale 
 
32.  The current PWD system in Madhya Pradesh, constrained by the identified institutional 
and policy constraints can not perform responsibly and be accountable for effective sector 
management. It has resulted not only in rapid and dramatic deterioration of state road network 
but also substantial decrease in road use because of unreliable road transport services, and 
almost no transport services to the rural poor. This, in combination with inefficient management 
and  scarce  financial  resources,  has  constrained  Madhya  Pradesh’s  social  and  economic 
progress. Serious overstaffing of PWDGoMP exhausts about 67% of the total annual recurred 
expenditures,8 or about 29% of the total budget, reducing the amount of funding for road 
maintenance. This also contributes to substantially reduced incentive of PWDGoMP staff, poor 
governance, and an almost nonperforming infrastructure management. 
 
33.  Sector reform is crucial to rectify this situation, and enable MPG to manage state roads 
better, and ensure reliable road transport services to support the state’s economic and social 
development.    The  reform  will  help  foster  good  governance  in  public  administration  and 
accountability in public resource and asset management for the state road sector. Improving the 
sector capability and capacity will enable a transparent and conducive environment for more 
competition, which in turn will ensure better infrastructure facilities and decrease in recurrent 
costs  for  road  maintenance  over  the  medium-  and  long-term.  The  reform  will  also  initiate 
establishment of an enabling environment which will encourage more private sector participation 
in road projects by outsourcing professional services for road development and maintenance 
projects  through  competition  and  use  of  performance-based  contracts.  These  together  will

III.  THE PROPOSED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
 
 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
35.  The main objective of the SDP is to enable MPG to establish more effective and efficient 
management of state roads and ensure reliable road transport services to support Madhya 
Pradesh’s  social  and  economic  development,  and  thus  reduce  poverty.  The  objective  is 
expected to be achieved by (i) instituting measures for good governance in the administration 
and management of the sector, improving capability and building capacity for effective road 
asset management, improving road transport services and road safety, and initiating steps for 
better private sector participation; and (ii) rehabilitating priority state road corridors that have 
deteriorated significantly. The program and project frameworks are given in Appendix 3. 
 
B.  Important Features 
36.  Figure 1 of Appendix 9 illustrates the macroeconomic linkages of the proposed sector 
reform. Reforming the state road sector will enable MPG to manage more effectively manage 
state roads and ensure reliable road transport services to support Madhya Pradesh’s economic 
and  social  development  through  two  main  channels.  The  first  channel  includes  improving 
governance  in  public  administration  and  accountability  in  public  resource  and  asset 
management  for  state  roads.  Improving  the  sector  capability  and  capacity  will  create  a 
transparent environment conducive for increased efficiency and competition. This in turn will 
promote  higher  quality  construction  and  road  maintenance  and  more  sustainable  road

contributing indirectly to poverty reduction.

67.  The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  using  the  Highway  Development  and 
Maintenance Tools (HDM). The HDM in principle evaluates investments on projects in the form 
of capital and recurrent costs against benefits derived from the savings of road user costs for 
situations of “with” and “without” project. The rapidly deteriorating road network, the current 
traffic volumes, and future traffic forecast justify a rehabilitation program instead of upgrading 
and reconstruction. The rehabilitation will enable the road asset base to be preserved and thus 
avoid the need to reconstruct the roads in the near future. It will also reduce requirements for 
periodic maintenance. The improved road conditions are expected to attract more traffic and 
economically justify further the improvement. In the economic analysis, the project life was 
taken to be 20 years. 
 
68.  The analysis was carried out using generic traffic categories and road condition classes. 
Based on the current traffic mix, the overall traffic growth rate will be 6% per annum in the early 
years, from the completion of the Phase I rehabilitation works in 2005, to 2012, 5 years after the 
completion of the whole Project. The traffic growth rate after 2012 will fall to around 5% per 
annum. The annual traffic growth is slightly lower than the average national traffic growth rate of 
7% because of the slower economic growth in net state domestic products at 5% per annum 
compared to the 6% of the national average. Three rehabilitation options were considered 
based on traffic level and road condition categories. The main quantifiable benefits of the 
investment are (i) savings in vehicle operating costs (VOCs) for existing traffic, (ii) VOC savings 
to generated traffic, and (iii) time saving. A minor component is the savings in maintenance 
costs to be incurred by PWDGoMP. The VOC savings are generated through better road 
surface conditions. As the access to markets, which reflects agricultural benefits, becomes 
better, increased economic activities will generate more traffic. 
 
69.  The HDM will enable PWDGoMP to plan and program the state road maintenance 
budget so that resources are allocated according to where they will have the most economic 
impact. This will improve resource allocation. The labor rationalization program will reduce 
redundant staff and increase financial resources for road maintenance works. The modern 
financial  management  systems  and  improved  business  processes  will  increase  use  of 
competitive bidding to obtain better prices and outputs in maintenance services.

70.  Madhya Pradesh is one of the largest and most populated states in India, and  one of

be improved. Of these, an estimated 5 million poor people will be direct beneficiaries, or about 
50% of the total direct beneficiaries.10 A detailed project beneficiary count and distribution of net

72.  The benefits will become evident in higher agricultural product profit margins for poor

1.  This sector analysis supplements the analysis in the main text and focuses on analysis 
of  the  current  road  maintenance  system.  Madhya  Pradesh’s  road  network  is  substantially

attributable to three factors: 
 
(i)  Lack of funding for road maintenance and lack of effective overloading control 
have resulted in severe damage of most of the road network and part of the rural 
roads.  
(ii)  The  road  maintenance  equipment  is  inadequate  and  obsolete,  and  Madhya 
Pradesh Government (MPG) can not finance restoring the equipment to meet

(iii)  The  Public  Works  Department  of  the  Government  of  Madhya  Pradesh

maintenance.

maintenance has been carried out by labor without any technical capacity or required skills. 
PWDGoMP has a very poor maintenance planning and management system.

for the routine maintenance are provided by the PWD, or locally procured by the PWD local 
branch offices. 
 
10.  Routine maintenance normally includes patching; crack sealing; cleaning of ditches; 
dressing of slopes; trimming of tree branches; and white washing of safety posts, parapets, and 
hill cut slopes. 
 
E.  Periodic Maintenance 
11.  For  periodic  maintenance,  officers  in  charge  of  particular  sections  prepare  their 
proposals based on their inspections, which mostly visual without appropriate testing. They then 
prepare assessment reports and detailed itemized estimates of materials needed. Normally, 
drawings are prepared manually for supplementary reference to the detailed estimates. 
 
12.  The estimates are mainly prepared for periodic maintenance activities scheduled over 6–
8 years. In most of the cases, the type of treatment is predetermined without any substantiating 
investigations on actual road conditions and performance indicators. 
 
13.  To carry out periodic maintenance activities generally known as “renewals,” PWD has 
trucks, bitumen boilers, static rollers and drum mix plants. However, due to the ineffective 
recovery of capitals, maintenance, and operational cost, the equipment has not been fully used

or maintained, and has become obsolete. No budget allocations have been made to operate or 
refurbish the equipment. 
 
14.  Rates for manual and mechanized works normally used are published by PWD. The 
rates are estimates based on approved sources of material and established average lead 
distances to the nearest sources. 
  
F.  Business Process for Periodic Maintenance 
15.  The  business  process  for  periodic  maintenance  is  initiated  at  the  section  level  by 
collecting data on road conditions and updating the maintenance activity chart based on the last 
periodic maintenance. The estimates are then forwarded to subdivisional officers for scrutiny 
and verification, then to the divisional officer/executive engineer. The engineer compiles the 
data  at  the  divisional  level,  with  details  of  the  previous  year’s  allocation  to  the  sections 
concerned. 
 
16.  The zonal level details are further compiled from each division by the chief engineer. The 
chief engineer prepares a summary estimate detailing the total number of kilometers to be 
maintained, and number of structures to be repaired or replaced. These details are forwarded to 
the engineer-in-chief. The engineer-in-chief compiles the data with the assistance of the chief 
engineer (planning) and issues job orders for periodic maintenance. There is no database on 
any of the road sections for either long term or short term planning use at PWD headquarters. 
 
17.  As  part  of  preparing  estimates  for  periodic  maintenance,  and  to  rationalize  the 
maintenance program, the PWD manual specifies the following data collection frequencies: (i) 
traffic count-twice a year, (ii) road condition-once a year, and (iii) condition of structure—once a 
year.  However, these are not being implemented due to lack of funding and expertise. 
 
G.  Budget Approval 
18.  The estimates prepared by the engineer-in-chief are proposed to the principal secretary 
along  with  other  requirements  for  budget  approval.  However,  funds  allocated  are  barely 
sufficient to meet even 50% of the proposals. Based on the approved budget, the engineer-in-
chief consults with the zonal chief engineers and chief engineer (planning) about distributing the 
funds. The PWD criteria for distributing funds are highlighted in the following: 
  
(i)  review of bar charts for the last 5 years on periodic renewal, 
(ii)  condition of the road and severity of the distress and the effect on delaying the 
planned activity, 
(iii)  intervention criteria based on road condition and the available grant, 
(iv)  implementation arrangements, and 
(v)  identification of eligible contractors.

The registrations are renewed or cancelled based on contractors’ performance. The registration 
and classification of contractors have been revised following the provisions in the PWD manual.

22.  Bids are evaluated based on the guidelines provided in the PWD manual. The guidelines 
have been updated recently, but have yet to be implemented. For bid evaluation, a committee is

the committee are yet to be tested.

The evaluated bids based on the financial quotes are negotiated for the award of bids. 
 
J.  Quality Control  
24.  Combined teams of the PWD and the contractor’s representatives normally carry out 
quality control. For small works, this mechanism is not practical. In most of the cases, this is not 
implemented, resulting in no supervision and quality control. 
 
K.  Monitoring System for the Performance of Contractor’s 
25.  Contractors  that  perform  poorly  are  not  allowed  to  bid  for  future  contracts.  New 
guidelines  are  yet  to  be  implemented  with  special  conditions  to  address  nonperforming 
contractors or irregularities in their execution of contracts. Payments are usually late due to 
funding constraints, and are made on a monthly basis. Contractors can not claim extra payment 
for the delay or chose the mode of compensation. The superintending engineers arbitrate claims 
for PWD.

26.  Subengineers  record  measurements  to  be  agreed  by  contractors.  Subdivisional

DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION MATRIX 
1.  Investment in road transport at present and for the next decade is a priority for India 
because (i) continued economic growth is essential for India’s efforts to fight poverty; (ii) road 
transport infrastructure can deliver major benefits to the poor, both directly and indirectly; and 
(iii) the deficient road transport system is a key constraint for growth in India. 
 
2.  The  Government  of  India  has  recognized  this  key  constraint  and  has  placed  road 
transport  as  one  of  the  major  priorities  in  its  current  investment  program.  In  addition  to 
mobilizing its own resources through a central road fund, the Government has sought a large 
amount of financial and technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and 
the World Bank, of about $2 billion per annum in the medium term. 
 
3.  To deliver the large program to India in an efficient manner given the limited resources 
faced by both organizations, ADB and the World Bank have developed a coordinated strategy 
for the road sector in India. Advantages of the coordinated strategy include (i) consistency in 
policy advice, (ii) cost effectiveness and avoidance of duplication of effort, (iii) greater focus on 
results through use of a common performance monitoring system, and (iv) operational synergy 
and complementary with each other in terms of sector knowledge and staff skill mix. 
 
4.  For the state road sector, a two-pronged strategy is being pursued. ADB and the World 
Bank have separate focal states, and selectively support a number of nonfocus states that have 
given assurances that (i) the support will not be wasted due to corruption or poor governance, 
and (ii) that have an unusually high development or demonstration impact for a particular project 
because of its innovative nature, or  the issue of the reform being promoted is important. 
 
5.  Consistent with state governments’ investment priority for state roads, ADB and the 
World Bank focused on capacity expansion of high traffic and high priority state road corridors 
and rehabilitation of high priority state roads to reduce the maintenance backlog.

7.  Since 1988, ADB has provided 7 loans totaling $1,536 million, 1 TA loan for $12.7

being prepared in consultation with the Government, World Bank, and other financing agencies.  
 
8.  ADB’s sector strategy is to reduce road infrastructure bottlenecks on the key transport 
corridors  to  support  India’s  efforts  to  achieve  higher  sustainable  economic  growth.  ADB’s 
approach is to promote efficiency in the delivery and maintenance of road infrastructure through 
appropriate policy measures and maximizing, where feasible, private participation. Within this 
strategy, ADB’s involvement in the road sector will focus on projects that have significant direct 
and indirect impacts on poverty reduction, facilitate subregional economic cooperation, and 
promote private sector development. Under the overall thrust of the focal state approach, ADB’s 
strategy for the state road sector focuses on reorganizing the outdated public works department 
system to improve its responsibility and accountability in sector management through instituting 
good governance measures, modern managerial capabilities, and capacity for more effective 
and efficient sector management and operation, thereby ensuring more efficient use of limited 
financial resources to free more expenditures and capital for priority social sectors for poverty 
reduction.

SUMMARY OF POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY 
 
 
A.  Contribution of the Sector Development Program (SDP) to Reduce Poverty 
1.  Madhya Pradesh is one of largest and the most populous states in India.  It is also one 
of the poorest in the country. About 38%  of the 77 million people in Madhya Pradesh live below 
the official poverty line,  compared to about 35%  of the population living below the poverty line 
for India as a whole. 
 
2.  The Program is classified as a poverty intervention and will directly reduce poverty by 
lowering the costs of transport for the poor traveling to labor markets, farmers’ markets, and 
health and education centers.  The Program will have a large effect on reducing poverty, directly 
benefiting 10 million people in a 30 kilometer zone of influence around the state roads to be 
improved.  Of these, an estimated 5 million poor people will be direct beneficiaries, or about 
50% of the total direct beneficiaries.  
3.   The estimated distribution analysis draws the selected road section and reflects that the 
poor and very poor are heavy users of motorized transit on the project roads and that as the 
roads  are  improved,  competition  in  passenger  and  freight  transport  markets  will  become 
stronger. Resultant lower transport costs will substantially be passed on to poor and very poor 
passenger and freight shippers. 
 
4.  For the baseline forecast, the estimated share of benefits accruing to poor and very poor 
passengers is the same as that in paragraph 3. For the net benefits accruing to freight shippers, 
the fieldwork supports estimates that 60% of the net benefits will accrue to the poor and 50% to 
the very poor,  who are included in the poor grouping. 
 
5.  These benefits will become evident in higher agricultural product profit margins and 
lower cost and more timely access to schools, medical clinics, and employment centers.  The 
lower transport costs will increase mobility among the poor, especially poor women, facilitating 
their  access  to  social  centers  and  enabling  there  to  become  more  politically  active,  thus 
increasing the empowerment of the poor. 
 
6.  The estimates do not include the expected benefits to the poor of improving the tertiary 
rural connectivity roads, which is a project component. These additional benefits likely will be 
substantial, because they link poor farmers and their villages with the state road system, which 
are currently impassable during the monsoon season. The rural connector roads to be included 
in the Project will be selected based primarily on poverty-reduction criteria during the design 
phase of the Project.  
 
7.  These estimates are based on surveys of over 150 passengers, 150 drivers, 50 freight 
shippers, and 27 residents in the zone of influence, along with 19 focus group discussions and 
direct field observations on a carefully selected representative sample of 525 kilometers of the 
state road system that will be improved by the Project.  This fieldwork was completed during 
March – April 2002.  The sample sizes and selected road segments are more than adequate to 
ensure that the results can be generalized to the entire project. Results conform to available 
secondary data and the results from key informant interviews.  Moreover, from a classical 
statistical viewpoint, the sample sizes are adequate based on the observed degree of variation 
in the estimated parameters of the target populations.

60  Appendix 12 
8.  The surveys reveal that 90% of the poor in the zone of influence use the project roads, 
and that a third of passengers on motorized vehicles are poor. The surveys and focus groups 
show that the degree of competition in the transport services market, including passenger and 
freight services, varies depending on the condition of the road. On roads in better condition, 
there is more competition, while on roads in very worn condition, traffic is low and competition is 
weak. This suggests competition will become much stronger as the roads are improved during 
the Project. With the poor being such heavy users of the roads now, and competition hindered 
by weak road conditions, the Project will catalyze competition and service frequency, thus 
reducing passenger fares and freight rates, and leading to even more intense use of the Project 
roads by the poor. The findings underpin the estimates of the Project’s estimated effects on the 
poor. 
 
B.  Participatory Process 
9.  Community  consultations  and  the  social  assessment  show  unanimous  support  for 
improving state and rural roads. According to the residents, poor road conditions increase the 
cost of access by the poor to health clinics, schools, labor markets, and farmers’ markets.  By 
improving the project roads, the poor residents see that these costs will decline and that they 
will have easier access to the key institutions that determine their quality of life. In the focus 
groups, improved access ranked among the top three critical needs identified by participants.  
Other top needs include improving the water management system, increasing the supply of 
electricity, and lowering the cost of education. The consultations also showed that the poor, 
especially the poor women, are concerned about road safety, and the lack of bus stops in the 
villages and hamlets. Residents are aware that the bad road conditions and lack of access 
increases the cost of retrieving farm inputs and delivering farm products to market, and that 
these high transport costs cut their farm incomes. 
 
10.  Based on the findings and recommendations from the community consultations, the 
design  consultant  will  incorporate  improvements  to  shoulders,  to  improve  the  safety  for 
pedestrians and nonmotorized traffic; covered bus stops with seating; wayside amenities; and 
truck stops, to reduce road congestion where necessary.  The improvements will be done if they 
do not entail land acquisition or resettlement. To address concerns about road safety, the 
design will include information signs and speed break near schools, hospitals, and areas heavily 
trafficked by pedestrians, such as towns and market. 
 
11.  The design consultant and Public Works Department of the Government of Madhya 
Pradesh (PWDGoMP) will create a consultative working group on labor relations, with stakeholder 
representatives, to prepare, implement, and monitor a labor retrenchment plan for PWDGoMP.  
The working group will provide a forum for counseling, stakeholder participation, information 
dissemination, and coordination with other government agencies.  The design consultant will 
provide a participation strategy to prepare, implement, and monitor the labor rationalization 
program (LRP). 
 
C.  Gender Issues 
12.  Research elsewhere in South Asia has shown that when access is difficult, men more 
actively participate in society than women.  When access improves, as it will under the Project, 
women become more mobile and more socially active; they will gain political empowerment and 
be better able to reach the centers of political activity. The Project will thus increase women’s 
empowerment.

13.  The  public  consultations  revealed  substantial  wage  differentials  between  men  and 
women providing the same labor.  The differentials favor men. The program will encourage 
employment  targets  for  women  to  participate  in  road  construction  activities  and  require 
contractors to pay the same wage to men and women for work of equal value. Targeting and 
providing a quota for women in road rehabilitation will provide employment opportunities where 
such  opportunities  are  scarce,  and  allow  women  to  increase  family  incomes.  During  the 
rehabilitation phase the contractors will be required to provide service stations that will ease 
working conditions for women who do take on the road works jobs.  A gender strategy is not 
required as a component of the Program. 
 
D.  Resettlement 
14.  The Program’s optimal engineering solutions for road rehabilitation do not entail land 
acquisition  or  resettlement.  The  rehabilitation  works  will  be  within  the  existing  alignments, 
focusing  on  improving  pavement,  drainage  and  shoulders.  The  program  will  not  entail 
dismantling of encroachments or land acquisition. Visual surveys along selected road sections 
indicated  few  exceptions.  The  existing  right-of-ways  are  adequate  to  accommodate  the 
proposed rehabilitation. 
 
E.  Indigenous People 
15.  Madhya Pradesh has about 20% of India’s scheduled tribe population, with the Betul-
Paratwada corridor having a high tribal population of near 40%. The Project, however, will have 
no  significant  negative  impact  on  the  tribal  population.  Thus,  an  indigenous  people’s 
development plan  is not needed.    
 
F.  Labor Issues 
16.  The Project will ensure that the civil works contractors comply with all applicable labor 
laws and do not employ children for construction or maintenance jobs. Contractors will be 
required to provide appropriate facilities for child dependants in construction campsites. 
 
17.  PWDGoMP employs 9,520 permanent staff and 20,000 casual workers, and is seriously 
overstaffed at the lower levels.  Institutional restructuring will require retrenching the labor force 
by about 30%.  Most layoffs likely will occur at the lower levels. To mitigate the social impact, 
the Madhya Pradesh Government (MPG) will establish a social safety net mechanism following 
the example of the program established under the previous ADB Madhya Pradesh Public 
Resource Management Program.  The MPG will approve, with technical assistance, the LRP in 
October 2002. See Supplementary Appendix B for a summary of the LRP. 
 
G.   Other Social Risks and Vulnerabilities 
18.  The  primary  risks  to  project  implementation  are  (i)  executing  agencies  and  other 
stakeholders lacking capacity to address social and poverty issues (ii) overlaps between the 
Department  of  Labor  and  PWDGoMP  could  impede  an  effective  retrenchment  plan  and  (iii) 
counterpart funds may be inadequate to implement the LRP. 
 
19.  The  project  design  incorporates  countermeasures  to  mitigate  these  risks.  The 
consultative group on labor relations will mitigate the risk of conflicts between the Department of 
Labor and PWDGoMP regarding the LRP.

20.  A very specific risk is that the poor may not be enable to capture the expected benefits.  
To ensure that the poor are able to capture these benefits, the design consultant will develop a 
program based on strong public participation in a number of workshops. These workshops will 
educate: 
 
(i)  poor farmers on to how to use commercial inputs and 
(ii)  poor farmers on how to best market their surplus products; 
(iii)  poor passengers on how to negotiate lower fares to reflect the cost savings going to 
the bus and taxi drivers;  
(iv)  poor shippers products on how to negotiate lower freight charges reflecting the 
improved road conditions; and 
(v)  poor women on increasing their political and social involvement in the community. 
 
21.  The design consultant, together with the Executing Agency and ADB, will develop and

particularly  poor  users  of  the  roads  as  well  as  residents  in  the  zone  of  influence.  Some 
illustrative indicators that show the benefits being passed to the poor will include 
 
(i)  improved construction materials being used by residents, and poor residents, for 
their dwellings in the zone of influence; 
(ii)  increases in commercial sales of specific farm products, including rice, wheat, gram, 
and sorghum from the zone of influence; 
(iii)  lower passenger fares on improved roads; and
